news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/updates.asp?id=70497|title=Two suspects accused of Liberty ambush held|date=5 March 2009|publisher=The News(Pakistani newspaper)|accessdate=2009-03-05}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} | numpart = | dfens = [[Punjab Police (Pakistan)|Punjab Police]]/[[Elite Police]] }} {{Pakistan terrorist attacks}} The '''2009 attack on the [[Sri Lanka national cricket team]]''' occurred on 3 March 2009, when a bus carrying [[Sri Lanka]]n [[cricket]]ers, part of a larger convoy, was fired upon by 12 gunmen near [[Gaddafi Stadium]] in [[Lahore]], [[Pakistan]]. The cricketers were on their way to play the third day of the second [[Test cricket|Test]] against the [[Pakistani cricket team]]. Six members of the Sri Lanka national cricket team were wounded. Six Pakistani policemen and two civilians were killed.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/7920260.stm|title= Gunmen shoot Sri Lanka cricketers|date=3 March 2009|work=BBC News|accessdate=3 March 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090304020128/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/in_depth/7920260.stm| archivedate= 4 March 2009 | deadurl= no|publisher=[[BBC]]}} The attack was believed to have been carried out by [[Lashkar-e-Jhangvi]]. In August 2016, three of the terrorists involved in the attack were killed during a police raid in Lahore.[http://tribune.com.pk/story/1171349/terrorists-involved-sri-lankan-cricket-team-attack-killed-lahore-raid/ Terrorists involved in Sri Lankan cricket team attack killed in Lahore raid] In October, the attack's mastermind was killed in eastern [[Afghanistan]] during a military operation, while hiding there.[http://tribune.com.pk/story/1196066/sri-lanka-cricket-team-attack-mastermind-killed-afghanistan/ ri Lanka cricket team attack mastermind 'killed' in Afghanistan] ==Background of the tour== The safety of touring cricket teams in Pakistan had long been an issue. In May 2002, [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] abandoned their Test series in Pakistan after a [[2002 Karachi bus bombing|suicide bomb attack]] outside their hotel. However, they returned in the 2003/2004 season to fulfill their commitments.{{cite web|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/newzealand/engine/series/61139.html |title=New Zealand in Pakistan ODI Series, 2003/04 |publisher=Cricinfo |date= |accessdate=2011-12-17}} [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] had recently refused to tour on safety grounds.{{Cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/stories/s644978.htm|title=Australian cricket team cancel Pakistan tour|last=Knight|first=Ben |date=9 August 2002|work=ABC News|accessdate=3 March 2009}} [[Sri Lankan cricket team in Pakistan in 2008–09|The Sri Lankan cricket team was in Pakistan]] as a replacement for the [[India national cricket team|Indian team]], who had pulled out after the [[Mumbai attacks]].{{Cite news|url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/pakistan/content/story/383401.html|title=Sri Lanka have confirmed tour – Pakistan board|date=10 December 2008|work=Cricinfo Pakistan|accessdate=3 March 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090208034909/http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/pakistan/content/story/383401.html| archivedate=8 February 2009| deadurl= no}} In order to persuade the Sri Lankan team to visit, the Pakistan government offered to give them presidential-style security.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/04/world/asia/04pstan.html|title=For Pakistan, Attack Exposes Security Flaws |last=Perlez|first=Jane|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-03-04| date=3 March 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090402020739/http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/04/world/asia/04pstan.html| archivedate=2 April 2009| deadurl= no}} The series was the first Test tour of Pakistan since South Africa visited in October 2007.{{cite web|url=http://content-www.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/series/298999.html |title=Cricinfo – South Africa in Pakistan Test Series, 2007/08 |publisher=Content-www.cricinfo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-17}} ==Attack== [[File:Location of 2009 Liberty chowk attack.png|thumb|left|250px|Black/grey depicts the route for team convoy. The escape route for attackers is shown in blue.]] According to the officials, 12 gunmen were hiding near Liberty Square, in the centre of Lahore, waiting for the Sri Lankan team to pass on their way to the Gaddafi stadium. They started firing at the bus when it crossed the road. The [[Pakistan police]] escorting the team returned fire; in the ensuing fighting, six policemen and two civilians died. After about 20 minutes, the militants fled, leaving behind rocket launchers and grenades. The gunmen first shot at the wheels of the bus, and then fired at the bus itself and its occupants.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/international/srilanka/4931223/Sri-Lankans-safe-and-out-of-danger-after-Pakistan-terror-attack.html|title=Sri Lankans 'safe and out of danger' after Pakistan terror attack|date=3 March 2009|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|accessdate=3 March 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090307084008/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/international/srilanka/4931223/Sri-Lankans-safe-and-out-of-danger-after-Pakistan-terror-attack.html| archivedate= 7 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} The attackers had fired a rocket at the bus, which missed and hit a nearby electric pole. The driver of the bus, Mehar Mohammad Khalil, had then kept on driving a distance of about {{Convert|500|m|ft}} until they reached the stadium. Khalil was hailed as a hero for his bravery.{{Cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/001200903181732.htm|title=Pakistan honours bus driver Khalil for his brave act |date=18 March 2009|work=[[The Hindu]]|accessdate=2009-03-29|location=Chennai, India| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090322124217/http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/001200903181732.htm| archivedate= 22 March 2009 | deadurl= yes}}{{cite web | url=http://www.news18.com/cricketnext/news/man-who-saved-sri-lankan-team-in-2009-lahore-attack-still-traumatised-995354.html | title=Man who saved Sri Lankan team in 2009 Lahore attack still traumatised | work=[[Network18]] | date=August 17, 2015 | accessdate=May 27, 2017 | agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]}} The attackers had also thrown a grenade under the bus, which exploded after the bus had passed over it. A minivan following the team bus carrying the match referee and umpires was also fired upon and the driver was killed. [[Simon Taufel]], [[Steve Davis (umpire)|Steve Davis]], [[Nadeem Ghauri]], [[Ahsan Raza]], umpires performance manager Peter Manuel, liaison officer Abdul Sami and ICC match referee [[Chris Broad]] were in this minivan. The minivan was subsequently allegedly abandoned by security personnel and no bullets were fired by the security forces for twenty minutes. [[Chris Broad]] threw himself over and kept his hand on the chest of [[Ahsan Raza]] to slow down the profuse bleeding from a bullet injury. A police officer who climbed into the minivan to seek cover drove the minivan to safety. Security cameras captured footage of several gunmen carrying automatic weapons and backpacks, firing on the convoy from the Liberty Square roundabout.{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/03/02/pakistan.srilanka.attack/ |title=6 dead in attack on Sri Lankan cricketers |date=3 March 2009 |publisher=[[CNN]] |accessdate=2009-03-04 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306212512/http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/03/02/pakistan.srilanka.attack/ |archivedate= 6 March 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} They were later seen jogging up the street and escaping on motorcycles.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/asiapcf/03/04/pakistan.srilanka.attack/|title=Pakistan hunts for cricket attack gunmen|date=4 March 2009|publisher=CNN|accessdate=2009-03-04}} The video was broadcast around the world presenting pictures of the attacks. [[CCTV]] footage has been made public.{{Cite news|url=http://www.geo.tv/3-4-2009/36532.htm|title=Geo news airs exclusive footage of Lahore attackers|date=4 March 2009|publisher=[[Geo TV]] |accessdate=2009-03-05| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090308235745/http://www.geo.tv/3-4-2009/36532.htm| archivedate= 8 March 2009 | deadurl= yes}} They arrived at 8:39 am local time and left at 8:46 am. The attackers were armed with [[AK-47]] assault rifles, [[hand grenades]], [[Rocket-propelled grenade|RPG]] launchers, [[M18A1 Claymore Antipersonnel Mine|claymore]]s and [[explosive charge]]s.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/Dawn%20Content%20Library/dawn/news/pakistan/punjab/Mumbai-terror-visits-Lahore-hs |title=Mumbai terror visits Lahore |last=Faisal Ali |first=Muhammad |author2=Husnain Ghayoor |date=5 March 2009 |publisher=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] |accessdate=2009-03-05 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/top_story_detail.asp?Id=20746|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120912204716/http://www.thenews.com.pk/top_story_detail.asp?Id=20746|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 September 2012|title=Several Lahore attack suspects arrested|last=Perwaiz|first=Salis bin|date=5 March 2009|publisher=[[The News International]] |accessdate=2009-03-05}} The Sri Lankan team were then taken to the stadium and airlifted from the pitch via [[Pakistan Air Force]] [[Mil Mi-17|Mil Mi-17 helicopter]]s,{{Cite news|url=http://www.geosuper.tv/news_detail.asp?id=14410|title=Sri Lankan team being evacuated by helicopter|publisher=[[Geo Super]]|accessdate=2009-03-03}} and immediate arrangements were made for the Sri Lankan team to return to [[Colombo]] on the next available flight.{{Cite news|url=http://cricketnext.in.com/news/tour-cancelled-after-lanka-team-is-fired-at/38740-13.html|title=Lankan players escape with minor injuries in attack|accessdate=2009-03-03| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090306113004/http://cricketnext.in.com/news/tour-cancelled-after-lanka-team-is-fired-at/38740-13.html| archivedate= 6 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} The second Test, which was the last scheduled fixture of the tour, was abandoned as a draw.{{cite web |subscription=yes |url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/211/211023/211023_bbb.html|title=Pakistan v Sri Lanka in 2008/09|date=3 March 2009|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=3 March 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090304182846/http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/211/211023/211023_bbb.html| archivedate= 4 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} ==Injuries== Several team members sustained minor wounds, including:[[File:Mahela Jayawardene.jpg|150px|right|thumb|Sri Lankan captain [[Mahela Jayawardene]] was one of those injured.]] * [[Thilan Samaraweera]] * [[Kumar Sangakkara]] (vice-captain) * [[Tharanga Paranavitana]] * [[Ajantha Mendis]] * [[Chaminda Vaas]] * [[Mahela Jayawardene]] (captain) * [[Suranga Lakmal]] Six Pakistani policemen and two civilians were killed in the attack.{{Cite news|url=http://www.skynews.com.au/news/article.aspx?id=308388 |title=Sri Lankan cricket team in shooting |date=3 March 2009 |work=Sky News |accessdate=3 March 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304061017/http://skynews.com.au/news/article.aspx?id=308388 |archivedate=4 March 2009 |deadurl=yes }} Samaraweera and Paranavitana were hospitalised following the incident. The others had sustained minor injuries and shrapnel wounds.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/international/srilanka/4930665/Sri-Lanka-cricket-players-lucky-to-survive-terror-attack-in-Pakistan.html|title=Sri Lanka cricket players lucky to survive terror attack in Pakistan|last=Briggs|first=Simon |date=3 March 2009|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=3 March 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090307005622/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/international/srilanka/4930665/Sri-Lanka-cricket-players-lucky-to-survive-terror-attack-in-Pakistan.html| archivedate= 7 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} Samaraweera sustained shrapnel wounds to his thigh, and Paranavitana to his chest.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/international/srilanka/4931483/Sri-Lanka-cricket-attacks-Kumar-Sangakkara-injured-in-Pakistan-shooting.html|title=Sri Lanka cricket attacks: Kumar Sangakkara injured in Pakistan shooting |last=Briggs |first=Simon |date=3 March 2009|work=The Telegraph|accessdate=3 March 2009 | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090307002437/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/international/srilanka/4931483/Sri-Lanka-cricket-attacks-Kumar-Sangakkara-injured-in-Pakistan-shooting.html| archivedate= 7 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} The team's Assistant Coach [[Paul Farbrace]] was also injured.{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/7920306.stm|title= Lahore Test scrapped after attack |accessdate=2009-03-03 | work=BBC News |publisher=[[BBC]]| date=3 March 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090304172510/http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/7920306.stm| archivedate= 4 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} Although it was reported that Coach [[Trevor Bayliss]] also sustained minor injuries,{{cite news|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090303/ap_on_re_as/as_pakistan |title=Sri Lankan cricket team attacked in Pakistan |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=2009-03-03 |last=Ali |first=Rizwan |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090304184425/http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090303/ap_on_re_as/as_pakistan |archivedate=4 March 2009 |deadurl=yes }}{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5ibVbw8W41ERhnnfl-NybHJj2w4GA|title=Five Sri Lanka players injured – Sports Minister|publisher= [[The Press Association]] |accessdate=2009-03-03|last=|first=| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090306211025/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5ibVbw8W41ERhnnfl-NybHJj2w4GA| archivedate= 6 March 2009 | deadurl= yes}} it was later announced that this was incorrect. Reserve umpire [[Ahsan Raza]], who was travelling in a van for the umpires that was following the Sri Lankan team bus, was shot twice and taken to hospital.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-32829651 |title=In pictures: Pakistan readies for return of international cricket |accessdate=22 May 2015 |work=BBC Sport}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.sindhtoday.net/sports/70109.htm |title=Pakistani umpire critically injured in Lahore attack |accessdate=2009-03-03 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306212941/http://www.sindhtoday.net/sports/70109.htm |archivedate=6 March 2009 |deadurl=yes }} The driver of the minibus was killed in the attack.{{Cite news|title=Chris Broad hailed as hero after Lahore attack | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/03/lahore-sri-lanka-cricket | date=3 March 2009 | author=Bowcott, Owen | accessdate=2009-03-03 | work=Guardian | location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090304184958/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/mar/03/lahore-sri-lanka-cricket| archivedate= 4 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} ==Investigation and attribution== Immediately following the attacks, unnamed Pakistani authorities blamed the [[Lashkar-e-Taiba]] (LeT), a militant organisation banned in both Pakistan and India.{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article5838998.ece|title=All 14 gunmen escape after deadly attack on Sri Lankan cricketers in Lahore|date=3 March 2009|work=[[Times Online]]|publisher= Times Online |accessdate=3 March 2009 | location=London | first1=Jeremy | last1=Page | first2=Jenny | last2=Booth}}[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/strike-had-hallmarks-of-mumbai-massacre-1636831.html Strike had hallmarks of Mumbai massacre], [[The Independent]], 2009-03-03 Pakistani officials said that the attacks were similar to the Mumbai attacks. Most of the Pakistani press blamed Pakistani Islamist militants and [[Al-Qaeda]] for the attacks.[http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/world/world/general/two-dozen-held-in-lahore-as-fbi-director-arrives/1450770.aspx Two dozen held in Lahore as FBI director arrives]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[The Canberra Times]], 2009-03-o5 Police said that kidnapping was a possible motive, but police officials refused to comment on this. [[Sri Lankan Foreign Minister]] [[Rohitha Bogollagama]] said on 4 March that he could not rule out involvement of the rebel [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]] (LTTE) in the Lahore attacks.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thenews.com.pk/top_story_detail.asp?Id=20740|title=Lahore attacks| publisher=[[The News International]] |date=5 March 2009|accessdate=2009-03-05}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Some European intelligence sources supported this suspicion.{{Cite news|url=http://www.asiantribune.com/?q=node/15896 |title=TTE-Mujahideen link suspected in attack on cricketers |date=5 March 2009 |accessdate=2009-03-05 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090310071430/http://www.asiantribune.com/?q=node%2F15896 |archivedate=10 March 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} Sri Lankan military officials, on the other hand, were skeptical of LTTE involvement,{{cite news| url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29475541/print/1/displaymode/1098/| title=Gunmen attack Sri Lankan cricket team in Pakistan|last=Ali|first=Rizwan|date=3 March 2009|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|accessdate=3 March 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} and an LTTE spokesperson labelled reports of LTTE connection as 'not true'.[http://www.ptinews.com/pti%5Cptisite.nsf/0/4D51E3CCE683A84F65257570001B7F0E?OpenDocument Press Trust of India (2009), ''LTTE denies link to Lahore attack''.]{{dead link|date=December 2011}} A junior Pakistani cabinet minister said that the government had evidence that the attackers came from India, but [[Ministry of Information, Broadcasting and National Heritage (Pakistan)|Information Minister]] [[Sherry Rehman]] denied any government knowledge of Indian involvement.{{Cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/southAsiaNews/idINIndia-38317420090303?sp=true|title=Sense of crisis deepens in Pakistan after Lahore attack|first=Zeeshan|last=Haider|date=3 March 2009|work=Reuters|publisher=Reuters India|accessdate=3 March 2009}} On 6 March 2009, government officials had ruled out the involvement of Indian intelligence agency [[Research and Analysis Wing]] and LTTE and were zeroing in on Lashkar-e-Taiba.[http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/Dawn%20Content%20Library/dawn/news/pakistan/investigators+see+let+footprints+in+lahore+attack--sal-up Investigators see LeT footprints in Lahore attack]{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Dawn (newspaper)]], 2009-03-06[http://www.hindu.com/2009/03/06/stories/2009030658730100.htm Pakistan rules out Indian hand], [[The Hindu]], 2009-03-06 Sri Lankan Foreign Minister [[Rohitha Bogollagama]] was quoted as saying
From our point of view, there is no Indian involvement. India has helped us in our counter-terrorist efforts. I don't see a need for India to target the Sri Lankan cricket team.
On the morning of the attack, the Sri Lankan and Pakistani cricket teams did not depart from the hotel together, as they had done on previous days, and the Pakistani team's schedule was delayed by 5 minutes. Statements by Australian umpire Simon Taufel, match referee Chris Broad, and spin bowler [[Muttiah Muralitharan]], referencing this delay sparked [[conspiracy theories]] that the militants were acting on inside information.{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article5850290.ece|title=Five-minute gap fuels conspiracy theory over Lahore terror attack|author2=Jeremy Page in Lahore and Anne Barrowclough in Sydney |date=5 March 2009|publisher=The Times|accessdate=2009-03-07 | location=London|first=Fariha|last=Karim}} Later, Muralitharan expressed alarm at such interpretations of his comments and explained that he only suspected the gunmen to be monitoring the team movements.{{Cite news|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/03/06/theories-and-conspiracy-theories-on-lahore/?hp|title=Rumors and Theories About the Lahore Attack|last=Mackey|first=Robert|date=7 March 2009|work=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-03-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090310172928/http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/03/06/theories-and-conspiracy-theories-on-lahore/?hp| archivedate= 10 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] director [[Robert Mueller]] arrived in Pakistan the day after these attacks and met with Pakistani officials to discuss security issues and the Mumbai attacks.[http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2009/03/04/asia/AS-Pakistan-FBI-Director.php FBI chief in Pakistan after attack on cricketers], [[International Herald Tribune]], 2009-03-04 Interior Adviser Rehman Malik, told the [[National Assembly (Pakistan)#Standing Committees|National Assembly Standing Committee on the Interior]] that no evidence of LeT's involvement has been found so far, and that sufficient evidence has been surfaced pointing to involvement of a foreign hand. ===Security lapse=== The Investigation committee found three [[Superintendent (police)#Pakistan|Superintendents of police]] (SPs) to have neglected the initial warning.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/03/sri-lanka-cricket-team-attack-warning|title=Warning of attacks on Sri Lanka cricket team was ignored |date=3 March 2009|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2009-04-06 | location=London | first=Saeed | last=Shah| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090306104828/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2009/mar/03/sri-lanka-cricket-team-attack-warning| archivedate= 6 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} by [[Intelligence news|url=http://www.ptinews.com/apti%5Cptisite.nsf/0/E6DEDC1C0235C1E165257570004C81B7?OpenDocument|title=Pak investigators identify terrorists behind SL cricket team attack|last=|first=|date=5 March web|url=http://pakistancrickethighlights.info/behind-pakistans-inconsistency-in-limited-over-cricket|title=Attack on Sri Lankan team in Lahore}} Police in Punjab arrested over 250 suspects, including 4 who were said to be 'prime suspects'. Police called Muhammad Aqeel, who ran a sports bikes business in [[Islampura]], the mastermind behind the attack, and said that he had received a call from one of the militants at 9:05 am on the morning of the attacks asking for instructions. Though Aqeel was still absconding, his brother, Muhammad Faisal, had been arrested.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009\03\05\story_5-3-2009_pg1_1| title = Police widen hunt for 3/3 clues| date = 5 March 2009|accessdate=2009-03-05| work = [[Daily Times (Pakistan)|Daily Times]]}} Police also arrested Shahzad Babar of [[Rahim Yar Khan]] after a [[Subscriber Identity Module]] (SIM) card registered in his name was used in the attack along with eight others.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/Dawn%20Content%20Library/dawn/news/pakistan/suspects+arrested+in+sri+lanka+team+attack-rs|title=Suspects arrested in Sri Lanka team attack |work = [[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]| date=4 March 2009|accessdate=2009-03-05}} Security officials in [[Pakistan]] told [[The Times]] that most of the two dozen people arrested in connection with the attacks belonged to [[Jaish-e-Mohammed]], [[Lashkar-e-Jhangvi]], outlawed militant groups with close links to [[Al-Qaeda]].[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article5854505.ece Gunmen who attacked cricketers in Lahore 'had links to al-Qaeda'], [[The Times]], 2009-03-06 Aqeel, who is an activist of Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, escaped a police raid on his home in [[Kahuta]] on 9 March 2009.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article5875297.ece Lahore attack 'mastermind' escapes police raid in Punjab], [[The Times]], 2009-03-09 Also another gunman Zubair, aka Naik Mohammad, of Zubair, was arrested from Madina Colony, Walton Road in Lahore. He was a waiter at a hotel in Rawalpindi, when he was recruited by Sifullah. He went to [[Miram Shah]] and was trained in the use of different weapons. Other accused including Samiullah, alias Ejaz of [[Nankana Sahib District|Nankana district]], Adnan, alias Sajjad, Ajmal alias Ahsaan, Farooq, Ameer of Punjab [[Taliban]], and Umer, alias Abdul Wahab of [[D. I. Khan]], were still at large. The attack was planned at Tauheed Hotel, and a house rented for this purpose in Madina Colony, Walton Road. The [[auto rickshaws]] used in the attack were purchased by Samiullah. A secret investigative report has surfaced later prepared by the Additional Inspector General of the Crime Investigation Division, Punjab on 22 January 2009 outlining the potential threat to the Sri Lankan team.{{Cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/pakistan/11-police-track-mastermind-of-attack-on-lankan-cricket-team--il--04|title=Sri Lankan team attack ''[[DAWN (newspaper)]]'' condemned the attack and cited security loopholes.{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/Dawn%20Content%20Library/dawn/news/pakistan/lahore-attacks-in-the-urdu-press-ha |title=Lahore attacks in the Urdu press |date=4 March 2009 |publisher=Dawn(Pakistani newspaper) |accessdate=2009-03-05 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The [[Daily Times (Pakistan)|''Daily Times'']], blamed Al Qaeda and Lashkar-e Jhangvi in an editorial, stating, "International cricket is no longer possible in Pakistan; therefore we should stop accusing foreign teams of discriminating against Pakistan vis-à-vis India. The question here is of the survival of Pakistan, not of cricket."{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009\story_4-3-2009_pg3_1 |title=EDITORIAL: Al Qaeda strikes in Lahore |publisher=Dailytimes.com.pk |date= |accessdate=2011-12-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307203236/http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2009%5C03%5C04%5Cstory_4-3-2009_pg3_1 |archivedate= 7 March 2009 |df= }} The ''[[Daily Jang]]'', responding on Chris Broad, Simon Taufel and Steve Davis's comments, said that their "vivid description of the terrifying attack gives us an insight into how people everywhere will see the events of the morning of March 3." The paper goes on to say that "their candid comments will seal the fate of Pakistan cricket for some time to come". It also said that Pakistan "must give up complaining" and that "ways to liven up the game at the domestic level need to be reconsidered with renewed urgency".[http://thenews.jang.com.pk/daily_detail.asp?id=165953 First-hand nightmares – The News] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090827054147/http://thenews.jang.com.pk/daily_detail.asp?id=165953 |date=27 August 2009 }}. {{LKA}} – President, [[Mahinda Rajapaksa]], said, "I condemn this cowardly terrorist attack targeting the Sri Lankan cricket team. The Sri Lankan players had gone to Pakistan as ambassadors of goodwill."{{cite news|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle08.asp?xfile=data/international/2009/March/international_March182.xml§ion=international |title=Lankan president condemns attack |date=3 March 2009 |work=AFP |publisher=Khaleej Times |accessdate=3 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608195443/http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle08.asp?xfile=data%2Finternational%2F2009%2FMarch%2Finternational_March182.xml§ion=international |archivedate=8 June 2011 |df= }} Prime Minister [[Ratnasiri Wickremanayake]] said that "Sri Lanka and Pakistan share a [[Pakistan-Sri Lanka relations|very close relationship]] and we will take all steps to protect this relationship."[http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/000200903041941.htm Ties with Pakistan will continue: Sri Lankan PM] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103230016/http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/000200903041941.htm |date=3 November 2012 }}. The driver of the bus whose presence of mind saved the cricketers was hailed as a hero.[http://sundaytimes.lk/090308/News/sundaytimesnews_13.html Mehar Mohammad Khalil: A hero across borders], [[The Sunday Times (Sri Lanka)|The Sunday Times]], 2009-03-08 The Sri Lankan team praised the bus driver. Then-captain of [[Sri Lanka]] [[Mahela Jayawardene]] praised Khalil saying he owed his life to the driver. Spinner [[Muttiah Muralitharan]] gave Khalil his team shirt.[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2009/03/05/1235842498871.html Lankans home, thank bus driver ], ''[[The Age]]'', 2009-03-05. ===Supranational=== ===Others=== {{Flag|United Nations}} – Secretary General [[Ban Ki Moon]] strongly condemned the attacks according to UN spokesman Marie Okabe. She also added that "Any attack targeting civilians, in this case athletes, is despicable and unjustifiable, and we urge authorities in Pakistan to do all in their power to find the culprits and bring them to justice."{{cite web |url=http://india.gov.in/outerwin.php?id=http://www.ddinews.gov.in/International/International+-+Other+Stories/un+attack.htm |title=National Portal of India |publisher=India.gov.in |date= |accessdate=2010-09-20}} The [[International Cricket Council]] – Chief Executive [[Haroon Lorgat]] said:
We note with dismay and regret the events of this morning in Lahore and we condemn this attack without reservation. It is a source of great sadness that there have been a number of fatalities in this attack and it is also very upsetting for the wider cricket family that some of the Sri Lanka players and one match official have been injured in this attack. At this time our thoughts and prayers are with the injured people and also the families of those who have died.{{cite press release|url=http://icc-cricket.yahoo.com/media-release/2009/march/media-release20090303-5.html |title=ICC statement following terror attack in Lahore |date=3 March 2009 |publisher=International Cricket Council |accessdate=3 March 2009 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}
The [[West Indies Cricket Board]] made a statement through president [[Julian Hunte]] and said "It was a sad day for International Cricket", and gave their full sympathy to the Sri Lankan players and the umpires.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ixlQrMPilkjn3RssZ53ZHlbL-XuA xxx]. Indian and New Zealand players wore black armbands while playing their next One Day International as a show of solidarity towards the Sri Lankan players injured in the attack,[http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/007200903031813.htm Lahore attack: India, NZ players sport black armbands] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126153631/http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/007200903031813.htm |date=26 January 2012 }}, [[The Hindu]], 2009-03-03. as did Australia and South Africa while playing their next test.{{original research inline|date=November 2014}} ===Other countries=== {{AUS}} – Prime Minister [[Kevin Rudd]] also condemned the attack on the Sri Lankan cricket team, calling it "shameful and cowardly".{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/03/04/2507291.htm?section=sport |title=Rudd denounces 'doubly atrocious' Lahore attack |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)]] |date=4 March 2009 |accessdate=2009-03-04| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090308235928/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/03/04/2507291.htm?section=sport| archivedate= 8 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} He demanded answers from Pakistan after claims that police left Australians travelling with Sri Lanka's cricket team in the lurch as the bus was attacked. "I am sufficiently concerned about what has been said by the Australians that we need an explanation and we intend to get one."[http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/lahore-link-to-alqaeda-as-suspects-identified/1452965.aspx Lahore link to al-Qaeda as suspects identified] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090308053347/http://www.canberratimes.com.au/news/local/news/general/lahore-link-to-alqaeda-as-suspects-identified/1452965.aspx |date=8 March 2009 }}, ''[[The Canberra Times]]'', 2009-03-7. I read two, three names ... Samaraweera, Mendis ... I hope they are safe and will recover. ''[[The Guardian]]'', 4 March 2009. [[Match referee]] [[Chris Broad]] was also critical of the security provided. He stated that he and his colleagues were left like 'sitting ducks' in the trailing minivan during the attack.[http://uk.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idUKTRE5232PY20090304 "Broad slams security over Lahore attack"]. [[Reuters]], 2009-03-04. He also accused the security personnel of fleeing the scene.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/mar/05/lahore-terror-attacks-chris-broad "Police left us like sitting ducks, says referee"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 2009-03-05. He questioned why the Pakistan team which usually travelled with the Sri Lankan team was delayed by seven minutes that day and avoided being attacked.[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/asia/article5854504.ece "Seven-minute delay that kept Pakistan's cricket squad from harm"], ''[[The Times]]'', 2009-03-06. [[Javed Miandad]] was critical of Broad's comments and demanded that International Cricket Council ban him for life.[https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2009/mar/06/miandad-broad-ban-lahore "Miandad demands life ban for outspoken Broad"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 2009-03-06. [[Pakistan Cricket Board]] lodged a formal complaint against Chris Broad with the International Cricket Council on 9 March 2009.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/cricket/7934423.stm "Pakistan register Broad complaint"], ''[[BBC News]]'', 2009-03-10. Ijaz Butt, the head of Pakistan Cricket Board accused Broad of lying.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/pakistan/4944703/Sri-Lankan-cricketers-Pakistan-accuses-Chris-Broad-of-lying-about-terror-attack.html "Pakistan accuses Chris Broad of lying about terror attack"], ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', 2009-03-06. Umpire [[Simon Taufel]] also said that the umpire's minibus was abandoned while the players' bus was moved to the ground to evacuate the players.{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/03/05/2508022.htm |title=Aussie umpires slam Pakistan security arrangements |date=5 March 2009 |work=ABC News |accessdate=2009-03-05| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090306213458/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/03/05/2508022.htm| archivedate= 6 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} Criticising the security entourage for abandoning them and inability of the police to arrest the attackers Simon said, "You tell me why no one was caught. You tell me why. Supposedly 25 armed commandos were in our convoy, and when the team bus got going again, we were left on our own." Co-umpire [[Steve Davis (umpire)|Steve Davis]] said "he felt let down" by the security. International Cricket Council umpires performance manager for East Asia, Sri Lanka and Pakistan, Peter Manuel told ''[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]'' that the minivan carrying the umpires was basically abandoned by the security personnel: "It was unbelievable. Bullets were raining on us and not a shot was fired in our defense by the Pakistan security officials."[http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn+content+library/dawn/news/pakistan/we-were-basically-abandoned-szh We were basically abandoned']{{dead link|date=September 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Dawn (newspaper)|''Dawn'']], 2009-03-8. Sri Lanka coach [[Trevor Bayliss]] backed the comments made by [[Simon Taufel]], Chris Broad and Steve Davis criticising the security.[http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12123_5031669,00.html "Bayliss backs officials"], ''[[Sky Sports]]'', 2009-03-10. Intikhab Alab, Pakistan cricket team's coach, asked Chris Broad to apologise to his country and team due to the remarks he made against Pakistani police security.[http://dailymailnews.com/200903/13/news/dmsportspage01.html "Intikhab asks Broad to apologize for remarks"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090808065751/http://dailymailnews.com/200903/13/news/dmsportspage01.html |date=8 August 2009 }}, ''The Daily Mail'' (Pakistan). English cricketer [[Dominic Cork]] who was commentating in Pakistan on the series and who himself was caught in the attack later criticised the security and Pakistan Cricket Board chairman [[Ijaz Butt]].{{cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,12123_5009385,00.html|title=Cork slams PCB chief|date=5 March 2009|publisher=Sky Sports|accessdate=12 March 2011}} Sri Lankan bowler [[Muttiah Muralitharan]] said the security arrangement was the worst he had ever seen, and vastly inferior to that provided in [[Sri Lanka]]. He said "The security people we had didn't even seem to fight back. Were they professionals with enough training? They didn't seem to know what to do. I was surprised the terrorists were able to just reload the magazines and keep firing, and they never got caught. It was shameful. If this had happened in [[Colombo]] they would never have got away."[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2009/03/06/1235842584734.html "Lahore security was shameful, says Murali"], ''[[The Age]]'', 2009-03-06. Eye witness Habib Akram, bureau chief of [[SAMAA TV]] news channel, said that the gunmen were very calm as they moved and fired by turns and that there was hardly any fire returned by the police. His office overlooks the traffic circle where the incident took place.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601081&sid=akGSVrqD10aI&refer=australia |title=Pakistan Shows Tape of Gunmen Escaping After Attack (Update2) |date=5 March 2009 |work=ABC News |first=Khalid Qayum |last=Ed Johnson |accessdate=2009-03-05}} [[Closed-circuit television]] footage of the event reported by [[Geo TV]] showed four of the attackers walking or jogging away unchallenged from the site, into a marketplace while no policemen are seen. Former president and former army chief [[Pervez Musharraf]] criticised the police commandos inability to kill any of the gunmen, saying "If this was the [[Elite Police|elite force]] I would expect them to have shot down those people who attacked them, the reaction, their training should be on a level that if anyone shoots toward the company they are guarding, in less than three seconds they should shoot the man down."[http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-03-05-voa13.cfm "Pakistan Cricket Ambush Controversy Focuses on Security"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307112722/http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-03-05-voa13.cfm |date=7 March 2009 }}, ''[[Voice of America]]'', 2009-03-05.{{cite news |url=http://www.gulfnews.com/world/Pakistan/10292058.html |title=Elite force should have killed terrorists |last=Rehman Khan |first=Fasihur |date=5 March 2009 |publisher=Gulfnews |accessdate=2009-03-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307100348/http://www.gulfnews.com/world/Pakistan/10292058.html |archivedate=7 March 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Governor of Punjab province where the attack took place in Pakistan, gave medals and awards to honour valour and bravery of police officials for fighting the terrorists during the attack.[http://www.app.com.pk/en_/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=70205&Itemid=2 "Gallantry medals given to valiant police officials"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090827090514/http://www.app.com.pk/en_/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=70205&Itemid=2 |date=27 August 2009 }}, [[Associated Press of Pakistan]]. ==Aftermath== Insurance costs for cricket matches in India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka rose.Mayur Shetty (4 March 2009), "[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/Lahore-attack-Terror-cover-to-cost-more/articleshow/4220745.cms Lahore attack: Terror cover to cost more for IPL franchisees]". ''Economic Times''. The [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] team cancelled its December 2009 tour of Pakistan.[http://content-www.cricinfo.com/pakistan/content/current/story/393259.html "Pakistan's World Cup hopes under threat"]. Cricinfo. [[Bangladesh]] also put off a scheduled tour by Pakistan to Bangladesh."[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/cricket/7925471.stm Pakistan's tour of Bangladesh off]". [[BBC News]], 2009-03-05. Chidambaram]], said that the [[Indian Premier League]] should consider postponing the forthcoming [[Twenty20|T20]] league matches due to be held over 45 days from 10 April to 24 May 2009 in 9 Indian Sri Lanka will not allow Pakistan's isolation in cricket." In October 2017, the Sri Lankan cricket team [[Sri Lankan cricket team against Pakistan in the UAE in 2017–18#3rd T20I|returned to Pakistan]] for the first time since the attack to play a [[Twenty20 International]] match at the Gaddafi Stadium.{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/series/18037/preview/1120293/ |title=Lahore readies itself for that international feeling |accessdate=29 October 2017 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}} ==See also== {{wikinews|Seven killed in gun attack on Sri Lankan cricket team}} * [[Attack on Pakistani ambassador to Sri Lanka]] * [[2010 Togo national football team bus attack]] * [[List of terrorist incidents in Pakistan since 2001]] * [[Sri Lankan cricket team in Pakistan in 2008–09]] * [[Terrorism in Pakistan]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://www.theguardian.com/world/sri-lanka-cricket-team-attack The Guardian's portal on the attack] *[http://english.aljazeera.net/sport/2009/03/20093121222845373.html New captain Sangakkara interviewed after the attack] {{Cricket in Sri Lanka}} {{International cricket tours of Pakistan}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sri Lanka national cricket team attack}} [[Category:2009 in Sri Lankan cricket]] [[Category:Mass murder in 2009]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in Pakistan in 2009]] [[Category:History of Pakistani cricket]] [[Category:History of Sri Lankan cricket]] [[Category:Pakistan–Sri Lanka relations]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents on buses]] [[Category:Mass shootings]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in Lahore]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Pakistan]] [[Category:Violence in sports]] [[Category:Lashkar-e-Jhangvi attacks]] [[Category:Islamic terrorist incidents in the 2000s]] [[Category:Gaddafi Stadium]] [[Category:Accidents and incidents involving sports teams]] [[Category:Cricket tours abandoned due to terrorism]]

{{Distinguish|Anti-austerity movement in the United Kingdom}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox Civil Conflict |title=2011 England riots |image = [[File:Carpetright store after Tottenham riots.jpg|300px]] |caption = Firefighters douse a shop and flats destroyed by arson during the initial rioting in [[Tottenham]], London |date=6–11 August 2011 (although [[Copycat crime|copycat]] incidents continued after this period) |place=Several districts of [[Greater London|London]], [[Birmingham]], [[Merseyside]], [[Greater Manchester]], [[Nottingham]], [[Bristol]], and several other areas{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/interactive/2011/aug/09/uk-riots-incident-map |title=UK riots: every verified incident – interactive map |work=The Guardian |date=11 August 2011 |location=London |first1=Simon |last1=Rogers |first2=Ami |last2=Sedghi |first3=Lisa |last3=Evans}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/law-and-order/8689355/London-riots-all-incidents-mapped-in-London-and-around-the-UK.html |title=London riots map: all incidents mapped in London and around the UK |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=9 August 2011 |first=Sebastian |last=Payne}} |causes = Escalation of events following fatal police [[Death of Mark Duggan|shooting of Mark Duggan]] |methods=Rioting, [[looting]], arson, [[robbery|mugging]], assault, murder |result=Shops, homes and vehicles destroyed |casualties3=5 deaths{{cite news|title=Police were in war of words over riots|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/police-pollies-in-war-of-words-over-riots-20110813-1irg2.html|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=13 August 2011}}
more than 16 members of public were injured
186 police officers, 3 [[police community support officer]]s[http://www.pcs.org.uk/en/news_and_events/pcs_comment/index.cfm/id/6E377B58-2B83-4B3C-804DC75DEAB6DB22 "Police staff working rest days to cover riot workload"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110828134811/http://www.pcs.org.uk/en/news_and_events/pcs_comment/index.cfm/id/6E377B58-2B83-4B3C-804DC75DEAB6DB22 |date=28 August 2011 }}, Public and Commercial Services Union, 12 August 2011. as well as five police dogs injured{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/home/uk-news/article/16046035|title=Live Updates From Sky News Team And Twitter: Riots Spread Across London|publisher=BSkyB |accessdate=11 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811153947/http://news.sky.com/home/uk-news/article/16046035 |archivedate=2011-08-11}}{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/police-warning-on-vigilante-justice-after-english-riots/story-e6frg6so-1226112680585|title=Police warning on vigilante justice after English riots |work=The Australian|date=11 August 2011|accessdate=11 August 2011|first1=Peter|last1=Wilson}}|casualties_label=Reported fatalities and injuries}} The '''2011 England riots''', more widely known as the '''London Riots''' were a series of [[riots]] between the 6th of August and 11 August 2011, when thousands of people rioted in cities and towns across [[England]], saw [[looting]], [[arson]], and mass deployment of police, and resulted in the deaths of five people. Protests started in [[Tottenham]], [[London]], following the [[death of Mark Duggan]], a local man who was shot dead by police on 4 August.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14434318 |title=Riots in Tottenham after Mark Duggan shooting protest |publisher=BBC News |date=7 August 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2012}} Several violent clashes with police ensued, along with the destruction of police vehicles, a [[double-decker bus]] and many homes and businesses, thus rapidly gaining attention from the media. Overnight, looting took place in [[Tottenham Hale]] retail park and nearby [[Wood Green]]. The following days saw similar scenes in other parts of London, with the worst rioting taking place in [[London Borough of Hackney|Hackney]], [[Brixton]], [[Walthamstow]], [[Peckham]], [[London Borough of Enfield|Enfield]], [[Battersea]], [[Croydon]], [[Ealing]], [[Barking, London|Barking]], [[Woolwich]], [[Lewisham]] and [[East Ham]]. From 8 to 10 August, other towns and cities in England (including [[Birmingham]], [[Coventry]], [[Leicester]], [[Derby]], [[Wolverhampton]], [[Northampton]], [[Nottingham]], [[West Bromwich]], [[Bristol]], [[Liverpool, England|Liverpool]], [[Manchester]], and [[Salford, Greater Manchester|Salford]]) saw what was described by the media as "copycat violence". [[Social media]] sites including [[Facebook]] also featured rumours of further disturbances or details surrounding known disturbances which were later proven to be inaccurate; for instance there were rumours of disturbances in the town of [[Dudley]] and at the nearby [[Merry Hill Shopping Centre]], but no incidents in these areas were detected by police. Rumours of a hospital being targeted by rioters in Birmingham were also proven to be wrong, as were rumours of disturbances in the [[Heath Town]] district of Wolverhampton, which had witnessed a serious riot in May 1989. By 10 August, more than 3,000 arrests had been made across England, with more than 1,000 people issued with criminal charges for various offences related to the riots. Initially, courts sat for extended hours. There were a total of 3,443 crimes across London that were linked to the disorder.{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2011/08/25/london-riots-more-than-2-000-people-arrested-over-disorder-115875-23371068/ |title=London riots: More than 2,000 people arrested over disorder |date=25 August 2011}} {{As of|2011|8|15|alt=Along with the five deaths, at least 16 others were injured}} as a direct result of related violent acts. An estimated £200 million worth of property damage was incurred, and local economic activity – which in many cases was already struggling due to [[Great Recession|the recession]] – was significantly compromised. The riots have generated significant ongoing debate among political, social and academic figures about the causes and context in which they happened. Attributions for the rioters' behaviour include such social factors such as racial tension, class tension, economic decline and the unemployment that it had brought, as well as individual factors like criminality, hooliganism, the breakdown of social morality and the development of gang culture.{{ref|{{cite news|title=Britain's rioters count cost of unrest as order restored|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/08/12/uk.riots|publisher=CNN |date=12 August 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14532532|title=England's week of riots|publisher=BBC News|date=15 August 2011}}{{Cite news|last=Lewis|first=Paul|title=Tottenham riots: a peaceful protest, then suddenly all hell broke loose|work=The Guardian|accessdate=7 August 2011|date=7 August 2011|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/aug/07/tottenham-riots-peaceful-protest|location=London}}{{cite news|title=Tottenham in flames as protesters riot|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/aug/06/police-cars-attacked-tottenham-mark-duggan|work=The Guardian|accessdate=6 August 2011|location=London|date=6 August 2011}}}} ==Police shooting of Mark Duggan== [[File:Ferry Lane, Tottenham Hale - geograph.org.uk - 1767129.jpg|thumb|right|Ferry Lane, Tottenham Hale, location of the shooting]] {{main article|Death of Mark Duggan}} On Thursday 4 August 2011, a police officer shot and killed 29-year-old Mark Duggan during an intelligence-led, targeted vehicle stop procedure on the Ferry Lane bridge next to [[Tottenham Hale station]].{{refn|{{Cite news|title=Mark Duggan shooting: Bullets results 'within 24 hours'|publisher=BBC|date=8 August 2011|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14443311}}{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/44091979/ns/world_news-europe|title=Soul searching lies ahead as UK riots cool|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=11 August 2011}}}} The [[Independent Police Complaints Commission]] (IPCC) said that the planned arrest was part of [[Operation Trident (Metropolitan Police)|Operation Trident]], which at that time investigated gun crime within the [[Black British|black community]]. The incident had been referred to the IPCC,{{cite news|title=Man dead and police officer hurt in Tottenham shooting|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14412752|publisher=BBC News|date=5 August 2011|accessdate=6 August 2011}} which is standard practice if death or serious injury follows police contact.{{cite web |title=What does the IPCC do? |url=http://www.ipcc.gov.uk/en/Pages/what_do.aspx |publisher=Independent Police Complaints Commission}} After the shooting, the media widely reported that a bullet was found embedded in a police radio, implying that Duggan fired on the police. Friends and relatives of Duggan said that he was unarmed. The police later revealed that initial [[ballistics]] tests on the bullet recovered from the police radio indicate that it was a "very distinct" police issue [[hollow-point bullet]].{{cite news|title=Doubts emerge over Duggan shooting as London burns|author=Sandra Laville|author2=Paul Lewis|author3=Vikram Dodd|author4=Caroline Davies|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/aug/07/police-attack-london-burns|newspaper=The Guardian|date=7 August 2011|accessdate=7 August 2011}}{{cite news|last=Gabbatt|first=Adam|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/blog/2011/aug/07/tottenham-riots-police-duggan-live#block-44|title=London disturbances – Sunday 7 August|work=The Guardian|location=UK|date=4 August 2011|accessdate=9 August 2011}} The IPCC later stated that a loaded [[Bruni Olympic .380 BBM|Bruni BBM]] [[Starting pistol|blank-firing pistol]], converted to fire live ammunition, was recovered from the scene.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/8699857/The-street-code-of-vengeance-that-sparked-the-riots.html|title=The street code of vengeance that sparked the riots|last=Lewis|first=Jason|date=13 August 2011|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=18 August 2011|location=London}}{{cite news|url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23976974-no-evidence-that-mark-duggan-shot-at-police-says-ipcc.do |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120919080804/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23976974-no-evidence-that-mark-duggan-shot-at-police-says-ipcc.do |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 September 2012 |title='No evidence' that Mark Duggan shot at police, says IPCC |date=10 August 2011 |work=London Evening Standard |accessdate=18 August 2011 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/264057/UK-riots-Mark-Duggan-had-a-loaded-pistol-|title=UK RIOTS: MARK DUGGAN ‘HAD A LOADED PISTOL’|date=10 August 2011|work=Daily Express|accessdate=18 August 2011}} It was wrapped in a sock and there was no evidence that it had been fired.{{cite news|title=The Independent Police Complaints Commission has just announced that there is no evidence|work=The Guardian|date=9 August 2011|accessdate=9 August 2011|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/blog/2011/aug/09/london-riots-day-four-live-blog#block-63|location=London|first1=Sam|last1=Jones|first2=Matt|last2=Wells|first3=Paul|last3=Owen|first4=Ben|last4=Quinn}} On 13 August, the IPCC stated that Duggan did not open fire: "It seems possible that we may have verbally led journalists to [wrongly] believe that shots were exchanged". The bullet that had lodged in an officer's radio is believed to have been an [[overpenetration]], having passed through Duggan's body.[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/mark-duggan-did-not-fire-his-weapon-at-police/story-e6frg6so-1226111938756 "Mark Duggan did not fire his weapon at police",] ''[[The Australian]]'', 10 August 2011.[https://archive.is/20130111160854/http://www.presstv.ir/detail/193718.html "Media misled on Mark Duggan death",] [[Press TV]], 13 August 2011. At lunchtime on 6 August, a meeting was called by police between local community leaders, councillors and members of police advisory groups. In this meeting, police were warned several times that there could possibly be another riot similar to the [[Broadwater Farm riot]] of 1985 if local concerns regarding the death were not addressed.{{Cite news|title=Tottenham in flames as riot follows protest|publisher=Channel 4|location=London|accessdate=16 September 2011|date=19 August 2011|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/could-the-tottenham-riots-have-been-prevented}}{{Cite news|last=Stephenson|first=Wesley|title=Tottenham police 'could have stopped riots'|publisher=BBC|location=London|accessdate=16 September 2011|date=25 August 2011|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-14646187}} On 8 January 2014, a jury at the [[Royal Courts of Justice]] concluded that Duggan was [[Lawful killing|lawfully killed]]. ===Protest march=== On Saturday 6 August, a protest was held, initially peacefully, beginning at [[Broadwater Farm]] and finishing at Tottenham police station.{{Cite news|last=Bolesworth|first=Sarah|author2=Barry Neild |author3=Peter Beaumont |author4=Paul Lewis |author5=Sandra Laville|title=Tottenham in flames as riot follows protest|work=The Observer|location=London|accessdate=7 August 2011|date=7 August 2011|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/aug/06/tottenham-riots-protesters-police}} The protest was organised by friends and relatives of Duggan to demand justice for the family.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14423942|title=Tottenham police shooting: Dead man was minicab passenger|publisher=BBC News|date=5 August 2011|accessdate=7 August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/police-patrol-tottenham-after-riots|title=Tottenham riots are a disgrace, says MP|publisher=Channel 4 |accessdate=7 August 2011}} The group of some 300 people demanded that a senior local police officer come out to speak to them. When Chief Inspector Ade Adelekan arrived, he was met with boos and cries of "murderer", "[[Uncle Tom#Epithet|Uncle Tom]]" and "[[List of ethnic slurs#C|coconut]]".[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/london-riots--one-year-on-owen-jones-commences-a-series-of-special-reports-7965142.html "London riots – one year on: Owen Jones commences a series of special reports", ''The Independent''], 23 July 2012. The crowd stayed in front of the police station hours longer than they originally planned because they were not satisfied with the seniority of the officers available at the time. Rumours that a 16-year-old girl had sustained injuries after attacking police with a champagne bottle began circulating on social media. To date, the girl remains unidentified and the report unconfirmed. However the rumour alone was sufficient to further fuel tensions in the area.[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/sep/05/tottenham-riots-police-community "Tottenham riots: missteps in the dance of police and a frustrated community" by Hugh Muir], ''The Guardian'', 5 September 2011. ==Riots== {{see also|Timeline of the 2011 England riots}} [[File:Fireman in action at Tottenham riots 2011 aftermath-crop.jpg|thumb|A firefighter douses a blaze in Tottenham during the aftermath of the initial riot]] A peaceful march on Saturday 6 August in Tottenham was followed by rioting and looting, first in Tottenham and later in Tottenham Hale Retail Park.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-10321233 |title=England riots: Maps and timeline|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=17 August 2011|date=11 August 2011}} Rioting occurred shortly after about 120 people marched from the Broadwater Farm estate to Tottenham Police Station via the High Road.[http://www.harrowobserver.co.uk/west-london-news/world-uk-news/2011/08/07/eight-officers-hurt-as-riots-erupt-116451-29192283 "Eight officers hurt as riots erupt"], ''Harrow Observer'', 7 August 2011. Retrieved 17 August 2011. The spread of news and rumours about the previous evening's disturbances in Tottenham sparked riots during the night of Sunday 7 August in the London districts of Brixton, Enfield, Islington and [[Wood Green]] and in Oxford Circus in the centre of London. [[File:Tottenham riots August 6th.jpg|thumb|left|Rioters facing police on the evening of 6 August 2011]] The morning of Monday 8 August was quiet, but by evening, areas across London were affected by widespread looting, arson and violence, with significant outbreaks in parts of Battersea, Brixton, Bromley, Camden, Croydon, Ealing, East Ham, Hackney, Harrow, Lewisham, Peckham, Stratford, Waltham Forest, Woolwich, and Wood Green. A man was found shot in Croydon, and died later in hospital. Another man who had been assaulted in Ealing died in hospital on Thursday 11 August. Similar riots were reported outside London – notably in Birmingham, Bristol, Gloucester, Gillingham and Nottingham.{{cite news |title=Just the job to bring riots to capital? |date=18 August 2011 |work=The Scotsman |url=http://www.scotsman.com/opinion/Ross-Martin-Just-the-job.6820832.jp}}{{Dead link|date=March 2012}} [[File:2011 London riots.jpg|thumb|Rioters attempt to loot a cycle shop in Chalk Farm, Camden]] Following a greatly increased police presence, London was quiet on Tuesday 9 August, but rioting continued in Nottingham and Birmingham (where, according to the police account, eleven shots were fired at police, including at a police helicopter, and petrol bombs thrown at officers{{cite web|url=http://www.west-midlands.police.uk/latest-news/appeal.asp?ID=4190 |title=Footage released after shots fired at police in Birmingham disorder |date=20 August 2011 |publisher=[[West Midlands Police]] |accessdate=20 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140728114513/http://www.west-midlands.police.uk/latest-news/appeal.asp?id=4190 |archivedate=28 July 2014 }}) and spread to Leicester, parts of the [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands]] and to parts of [[Greater Manchester]] and [[Merseyside]] in the north-west of England. On Wednesday 10 August, London remained quiet while hundreds of arrests were being made by the police. Three men were killed in Birmingham in a hit-and-run incident related to the disturbances. Looting and violence continued in two locations around Manchester and Liverpool. ==Social media== [[File:Barclays - 2011 London Looting.jpg|thumb|left|Bank workers in Walthamstow observe the destruction which was caused in the early hours of the morning]] Throughout the rioting, many of the rioters failed to cover their faces. Some posed for pictures with stolen goods, posting them on social-networking sites.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-14463452|title=UK riots: What turns people into looters?|accessdate=10 August 2011 | publisher=BBC News|date=9 August 2011}} Although London employs [[Closed-circuit television|CCTV]] cameras to monitor crime and large events, reports indicate that citizen footage contributed more to capturing looters in action than the police force.{{cite news|title=London and England riots: CCTV pictures of suspects are released by the police|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/picturegalleries/uknews/8690951/London-riots-CCTV-pictures-of-suspects-are-released-by-the-Metropolitan-Police.html|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=9 August 2011|accessdate=2015-05-17}} Beyond the CCTV, looters were filmed and photographed with their faces visible. Police forces and investigators used websites like [[Flickr]] to find galleries of the looters to help solve and prevent cases of vandalism and further damage. [[Facebook]] pages were also created to identify looters.{{cite web|last=Popkins|first=Helen|title=Citizen Cameras Capture more Looters than London Cops|url=http://www.technolog.msnbc.msn.com/technology/technolog/citizen-cameras-capture-more-london-looters-cops-121801|work=Blog|publisher=TechnoBlog|accessdate=28 March 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120420112134/http://www.technolog.msnbc.msn.com/technology/technolog/citizen-cameras-capture-more-london-looters-cops-121801 |archivedate=2012-04-20}} [[File:Liverpool Riots 2011 burnt cars.jpg|thumb|Burnt-out cars in [[Liverpool]].]] Several interactive maps were implemented in the [[Google Maps]] website that showed satellite views of what was happening in the streets during the rioting. James Cridland, the managing director of the free media resources, created a Google Map that tracked verified locations of rioting. [[Channel 4 News]] also had similar maps that progressively tracked the damage in the streets as well.{{cite web|last=Benedetti|first=Winda|title=Interactive maps reveal satellite's view of UK riots|url=http://www.technolog.msnbc.msn.com/technology/technolog/interactive-maps-reveal-satellites-view-uk-riots-121583|work=Blog|publisher=TechnoBlog|accessdate=27 March 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120508151113/http://www.technolog.msnbc.msn.com/technology/technolog/interactive-maps-reveal-satellites-view-uk-riots-121583|archivedate=8 May 2012|df=dmy-all}} News channels also were able to utilise this public service to capture live footage on the streets and inform citizens of dangerous or crowded areas. ===BlackBerry Messenger=== [[File:Croydon Riots 2011.jpg|thumb|left|Stand-off between rioters and police in Croydon]] There were reports that the [[BlackBerry Messenger]] service was used by looters to organise their activities, and that inflammatory and inaccurate accounts of Mark Duggan's killing on social media sites may have incited disturbances.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/aug/08/london-riots-tottenham-duggan-blog#block-61 |title=London riots – live blog |author=Paul Lewis |date=8 August 2011 |work=The Guardian |location=UK}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/aug/08/london-riots-facebook-twitter-blackberry |title=London riots: how BlackBerry Messenger played a key role |author=Josh Halliday |date=8 August 2011 |work=The Guardian |location=UK}} One of the many messages shared between users was the following:
"Everyone in edmonton enfield wood green everywhere in north link up at enfield town station at 4 o clock sharp!!!!," it began. "Start leaving ur yards n linking up with your niggas. Fuck da feds, bring your ballys and your bags trollys, cars vans, hammers the lot!!"{{cite news|last=Ball|first=James|last2=Brown|first2=Symeon|title=Why BlackBerry Messenger was rioters' communication method of choice|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/dec/07/bbm-rioters-communication-method-choice|work=The Guardian|accessdate=28 March 2012|date=7 December 2011|location=London}}
[[File:Tottenham Riot-shops.jpg|thumb|A shop in Tottenham Hale Retail park after the looting]] [[Research in Motion]] assisted British police in tracking rioters who used BBM, stating, "We comply with the [[Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act]] and co-operate fully with the Home Office and UK police forces."{{cite news|last=Garside|first=Juliette|title=UK riots: Mobile phone operators help police to identify looters|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/aug/09/uk-riots-mobile-phone-operators|work=The Guardian|accessdate=28 March 2012|date=9 August 2011|location=London}} Increased connectivity among individuals has led to a greater ability to organise and execute massive gatherings.{{cite journal|last=Jurgenson|first=N.|title=When atoms meet bits: social media, the mobile web and augmented revolution|journal=Future Internet|year=2012|volume=4|pages=83–91}} This has not occurred only with the riots in England, but with other collective gatherings such as the [[Arab Spring]] and the [[Egyptian revolution of 2011]].{{cite journal|last=Chebib|first=Nadine Kassem|author2=Sohail, Rabia Minatullah|title=The reasons social media contributed to the 2011 Egyptian Revolution|journal=International Journal of Business and Management|year=2011|volume=2|issue=3|pages=139–162}} ===Twitter=== Much like BBM, the mobility of technology shaped the London riots. During the Tottenham riots of 1985, citizens had to head into a public place to voice their message.{{cite news|last=Adams, Lee|first=William|title=London Riots: Organized via Twitter and Smart phones?|url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2087337,00.html|work=Time|date=8 August 2011}} Yet, with access to [[Twitter]] as a communication medium, social media was used to rapidly spread messages of the riots. Radio 4 criticised Twitter's contribution to the riots through greed and criminality.{{cite web|last=Williams|first=Olivia|title=London Riots: Twitter That Caused Them?|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2011/08/08/london-riots-twitter-that_n_920791.html|publisher=The Huffington Post- Canada}} ''The Daily Telegraph'' described Twitter as being an outlet for promoting gang violence. Evidence shows that Twitter is powerful because tweets of individuals were inspired by news content.{{cite journal |last=Tonkin |first=Emma |author2=Heather D. Pfeiffer |author3=Greg Tourte |title=Twitter, information sharing and the London riots |journal=[[Bulletin of the American Society for Information Science and Technology]] |date=13 January 2012 |volume=38 |issue=2 |doi=10.1002/bult.2012.1720380212 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/bult.2012.1720380212/pdf |pages=49–57}} However, an article in ''Time'' magazine suggested BlackBerry Messenger was more to blame. During the riots, Twitter accounted for four out of every 170 UK Internet visits on Monday 8 August. In addition, citizens also used Twitter to band together, after the destruction. The aftermath of the riots resulted in a disrupted city, yet Twitter was further used to maintain peace, with hashtags including "#riotcleanup". Evidence shows that people were tweeting and re-tweeting news related to the riots, not original content. ===Mobile phones=== Other than BlackBerry Messenger and social networking sites, mobile phone operators T-Mobile and Orange prioritised police requests for information about the phones that were used to plan the riots that hit British cities. Under the [[Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act 2000|Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act]], phone companies were required to hand over data about the locations calls were made from, the owners of phones, and lists of calls made to and from a particular handset. ==Effects== [[File:Firemen in action at Tottenham riots 2011 aftermath.ogv|thumb|right|A burnt-out building being doused with water. Built for the London Co-operative Society in 1930 as [http://www.apcg29.dsl.pipex.com/new%20goal%20for%20tottenham%20store.htm Union Point], the building included a [[Carpetright]] on the ground floor and many flats on the upper storeys.]] ===Deaths and injuries=== ====Trevor Ellis==== Trevor Ellis, a 26-year-old from [[Brixton Hill]], died following a shooting in [[Croydon]], [[South London]] on 8 August.{{cite news|title=A young man shot in his car|work=The Guardian |location=UK|date=9 August news|url=http://www.yourlocalguardian.co.uk/news/local/croydonnews/9189617.Suspected_looter_shot_dead_in_Croydon_named/ |title=Suspected looter shot dead in Croydon named as man from Brixton |date=11 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017074643/http://www.yourlocalguardian.co.uk/news/local/croydonnews/9189617.Suspected_looter_shot_dead_in_Croydon_named/ |archivedate=17 October 2013 |df= }}{{cite news|last=Judd|first=Terri|title=First fatality of the riots was decorator with a baby girl|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/first-fatality-of-the-riots-was-decorator-with-a-baby-girl-2336315.html|work=The Independent |location=UK|accessdate=12 August 2011|date=12 August 2011}} By 16 December 2013, 13 people had been arrested in connection with the murder. All were later bailed and then released without action. On 16 December, the eve of Ellis's birthday, detectives opened up a fresh appeal into the murder, asking for witnesses to come forward. As of 2018, no one has been charged.{{cite news|title=Seventh Arrest in Trevor Ellis Murder|work=The Voice |location=UK|date=15 March 2012|url=http://voice-online.co.uk/article/seventh-arrest-trevor-ellis-murder?quicktabs_1=1}} ====Haroon Jahan, Shahzad Ali and Abdul Musavir==== On 10 August, in [[Winson Green]], Birmingham, three men – Haroon Jahan, 21, and brothers Shahzad Ali, 30, and Abdul Musavir, 31 – were killed in a [[Hit and run (vehicular)|hit-and-run incident]] while attempting to protect their neighbourhood from rioters and looters.{{cite news | title = Three killed protecting property during Birmingham riots |publisher=BBC News | date = 10 August 2011 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-14471405}}{{cite news | last = Butt | first = Riazat | last2 = Wainwright | first2 = Martin | title = Birmingham riots: intense anger after deaths of three young men |work=The Guardian|location=UK | date = 10 August 2011 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/aug/10/birmingham-riots-anger-deaths | accessdate =10 August 2010}}{{cite news | last = Chazan | first = Guy | title = U.K. Ethnic Tensions Stoked by Riots | work=2011-08-11 | url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111904006104576499631544932082 | date=11 August 2011 }} On 19 April 2012, a trial of eight men, each [[Arraignment|arraigned]] on three counts of murder, was held in the Crown Court at Birmingham before Mr Justice Flaux; the jury acquitted all of the defendants on all charges.Press Association, [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/jul/19/eight-cleared-birmingham-riot-deaths "Eight men cleared of murder over Birmingham riot deaths"], ''The Guardian'', 19 July 2012. ====Richard Mannington Bowes==== [[File:Springbridge Mews floral tributes.jpg|thumb|right|Floral tributes at the site of the fatal assault. The flowers at the top spell out the word "why".]] A 68-year-old man, Richard Mannington Bowes, died on 11 August after he was attacked while attempting to stamp out a litter-bin fire in [[Ealing]] on the evening of 8 August.{{cite news|title=Ealing riot: Richard Mannington Bowes dies after attack|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14500869|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=11 August 2011|date=11 August 2011}} Bowes was attacked by members of a mob on 8 August 2011, while attempting to extinguish a fire that had been [[arson|deliberately started]] in industrial bins on Spring Bridge Road. The attack inflicted severe head injuries which resulted in a coma. The assault was caught on [[CCTV]] and reportedly filmed on mobile phones by associates of the alleged assailant.[http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/3750093/Fire-rages-around-riot-hero-Richard-Bowes.html "He paid a terrible price: Fire rages around riot hero"] by Anthony Price, ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]''. Retrieved 13 August 2011 The attack on Bowes was witnessed by several police officers, but due to the number of rioters they were unable to come to his aid until riot squad officers pushed back the rioters while being attacked to reach Bowes. A line of officers then held back the rioters as paramedics arrived. Bowes' wallet and phone had been stolen, and police faced difficulty in identifying him. He died of his injuries at [[St Mary's Hospital, London|St Mary's Hospital]] on 11 August 2011 after being removed from life support.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-14500869 "Riots: Arrest over death of Richard Mannington Bowes"] [[BBC News]]. Retrieved 12 August 2011.[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hFBZwbGfuldGsBSgvztwpfKPpkrg?docId=CNG.1dbda76336400d092358c2558c36e01d.51 "England riots claim fifth life, police defend tactics"] by Sam Reeves, [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]. Retrieved 12 August 2011 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140130145504/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hFBZwbGfuldGsBSgvztwpfKPpkrg?docId=CNG.1dbda76336400d092358c2558c36e01d.51 |date=30 January 2014 }} |url=http://www.ealinggazette.co.uk/ealing-news/riots/2011/08/11/boris-pledges-millions-to-help-ealing-recover-from-riots-64767-29221450 |title=Boris pledges millions to help Ealing recover from riots |archivedate=2011-10-07}} A sixteen-year-old male, later named as Darrell Desuze,{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/home/uk-news/article/16187825 |title=August Riots: Teen Who Killed Pensioner Named |publisher=Sky News |date=13 March 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120316010611/http://news.sky.com/home/uk-news/article/16187825 |archivedate=2012-03-16}} who lives in [[Hounslow]] was charged with the murder of Bowes, violent disorder and four burglaries.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-14526428|title='Witness' found over Richard Bowes death|publisher=BBC | date=15 August 2011}} He appeared at [[Croydon]] [[Magistrates' Court (England and Wales)|Magistrates' Court]] on 16 August 2011, where he was remanded in custody until his appearance at the [[Old Bailey|Central Criminal Court]] on 18 August 2011. His 31-year-old mother Lavinia Desuze{{cite web|url=http://www.4rfv.co.uk/nationalnews.asp?id=130553 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403032808/http://www.4rfv.co.uk/nationalnews.asp?id=130553 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 April 2012 |title=Teenager Remanded Over Ealing Riot Murder |work=4rfv.co.uk |date=16 August 2011 |accessdate=24 August 2011}} was charged with perverting the course of justice.{{cite news|last=Evans|first=Martin|title=Teenager charged with riot murder|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/8704678/Teenager-charged-with-riot-murder.html|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=16 August 2011|location=London}} On 12 March 2012 at the Crown Court at Inner London, Darrel Desuze pleaded guilty to manslaughter, after previously pleading guilty to burglary and violent disorder.{{cite web |url=http://news.sky.com/home/uk-news/article/16187198 |title=Teen Admits Killing Pensioner During Riots |publisher=Sky News |date=12 March 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120315003300/http://news.sky.com/home/uk-news/article/16187198 |archivedate=2012-03-15}} The following day the Crown withdrew the murder charge against (13 March 2012) After a trial at the Crown Court at Inner London before [[John Saunders (English judge)|Mr Justice Saunders]] and a jury, Lavinia Desuze was convicted of perverting the course of justice after she destroyed the clothing her son wore on the day of Bowes' death.{{cite web |url=http://www.westlondontoday.co.uk/wlt/content/mother-who-tore-riot-killer-sons-clothes-found-guilty
